column6: Violet ink has no advantage over other colors. The important point is to use the same color ink for correcting throughout

column2: Widely spaced isobars on a weather map indicate which of the following?
With what other stations may portable survival craft transceivers communicate?
column3: Communication is permitted between survival craft and rescue unit.
column4: Communication is permitted between survival craft and ship.
column5: Communication is permitted between survival craft.

column2: You are aboard a single- screw vessel (right-hand propeller) going full ahead with good headway. The engine is put astern and the rudder is placed hard left. The stern of the vessel will swing to:
column3: port slowly at first and then quickly to port
column5: port until headway is lost and then may possibly swing to starboard
column6: starboard until headway is lost and then to port

column2: You are approaching a pier and intend to use the port anchor to assist in docking port side to. When You would NOT use the anchor:
column3: the current was setting you on the pier
column4: another vessel is berthed ahead of your position
column5: the wind was blowing from the starboard side
column6: there is shallow water enroute to the berth

column2: You are approaching another vessel and see her signal flag "F" hoisted. What should you do?
column3: Change course to keep clear of the vessel because she is maneuvering with difficulty
column4: Continue on your present course since the vessel is signaling for a pilot
column6: Attempt to call the vessel on VHF radiotelephone because she is disabled

column2: You are approaching another vessel and see that it has the signal flag “O” hoisted. What is your next action?
column3: Proceed on present course and speed since the vessel is requesting a pilot to conduct a rescue
column4: Attempt to call the vessel on VHF radiotelephone and give a report because the vessel has a man overboard.
column5: Attempt to call the vessel on VHF radiotelephone and begin a search because the vessel has a recovered a man   overboard.
column6: Attempt to call the vessel on VHF radiotelephone and begin a search because the vessel has a man  overboard.

column2:
You are approaching the pilot station with the wind fine
on the starboard bow and making about 3 knots. You can help
to calm the seas by taking what action just before the pilot
boat comes along on the port side?
column6: A short burst of ahead full with left full rudder

column2: You are communicating by radiotelephone using the international code of signals. What is the correct method of sending the group 1.3?
You are conning a twin-screw vessel going ahead with rudders amidships. What will happen to the bow if the port screw stops turning?
column5: slowly turn to port and starboard

column2: You are evacuating crew members from a survival craft that has been adrift in the North Atlantic for several days. What could occur if a person suffering from hypothermia is vertically lifted in a rescue sling to the helicopter?
column3: Temporary blindness from the altitude change
column5: A decrease in the symptoms of hypothermia

column2: You are informed of defects or changes in aids to navigation by:

You are instructing new crew members in engine room safety and first aid. You use an example of "One crew member, while working in the engine room, finds another crew member lying unconscious on the deck." What would you instruct the crew do first when faced with the rescue of this crew member?
column3: Roll the victim over carefully and check the extent of the injury.
column4: Make sure they have all the proper equipment ready.
column5: Determine the extent of danger and their ability to cope with it.
column6: Make sure they summon help immediately.

column2: You are involved in a crossing situation with a vessel off your port bow. The other vessel is showing a high intensity all-round flashing red light. Which action should you take?
You are on a cargo vessel carrying portable tanks of dangerous cargoes in bulk. Which of the following statements is TRUE?
column3: If the tanks are pumped out while maneuvering onboard, each hose connection  must have minimum of three bolts.
column4: If the tanks are off loaded, no more than two tanks may be lifted together in a hoist
column5: When transferring sulfuric acid, you must display a red flag by day whether at anchor or moored
column6: All electrical equipment within three meters horizontally must be explosion proof or intrinsically safe

column2: You are on a vessel at 0400 ZT on 3 July, and the ZD for your position is -8. What is the GMT?
You are on an ice-reinforced vessel about to enter pack ice. You should __________.
column4: enter the pack on the windward side where there is a well defined ice edge
column6: look for areas of rotten ice and enter perpendicular to the ice edge

column2: You are on course 045°T, speed 12 knots. At 0930H you see a buoy bearing 015°T at a range of 5.0miles. If you maintain course at 045deg. T, the buoy will be abeam at a distance of:
You are on course 355deg. T and take a relative bearing of a lighthouse of 275deg.. What is the true bearing of the lighthouse?
You are on vessel “A” and hear vessel “B” sounding two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts. What does this indicate?
column3: “B” intends to overtake “A” on the starboard side
column4: “B: is overtaking “A” on the port side
column5: “B” is overtaking “A” on the starboard side
column6: “B” intends to overtake “A” on the portside

column2: You are on watch at night in clear visibility and the vessel has just been anchored. The first thing that you should do after the anchor has been let go is to:
column4: turn off the running lights and turn on the anchor lights
column5: lower the accommodation ladder and illuminate it
column6: take bearings to obtain ships position

column2: You are planning a voyage from San Francisco to Japan. Which publication contains information on the ocean routes?
You are planning to enter an unfamiliar U.S. port. Which publication provides information about channel depths, dangers, obstructions, anchorages, and marine facilities available in that port:
You are proceeding along the right bank of a narrow channel aboard a right- handed single-screw vessel. The vessel starts to sheer due to bank suction/cushion effect. You should:
column4: decrease speed and put the rudder right full
column5: stop engines and put the rudder left full
column6: increase speed and put the rudder right full

column2: You are proceeding to a distress site and expect large numbers of people in the water. Which statement is TRUE?
column3: If the survivors are in inflatable rafts you should approach from windward to create a lee for the survivors.
column4: Survivors in the water should never be permitted alongside due to the possibility of injury from the vessel.
column5: You should stop to windward of the survivors in the water and only use the ship's boats to recover the survivors.
column6: An inflatable liferaft secured alongside can be an effective boarding station for transfer of survivors from the boats.

column2: You are proceeding to a distress site where the survivors are in liferafts. Which action will assist in making your vessel more visible to the survivors?
column3: Dumping debris over the side to make a trail to your vessel
column4: Steering a zigzag course with 5 to 10 minutes on each leg

column2: You are proceeding to a distress site. The survivors are in liferafts. What will make your ship more visible to the survivors?
column3: Dumping debris over the side to make a trail to your vessel
column6: Turning on all available deck lights at night

column2: You are required to enter a lock on your voyage. Information on the lock regulations, signals, and radio communications can be found in:
column5: the publication Key to the Locks

column2: You are running parallel to the coast and take a running fix using bearings of the same object. If you are making less speed than used for the running fix, what will you be in relation to the position indicated by the fix:
column3: Will be on the track line behind the fix
column4: Will be on the track line ahead of the fix
column5: Will be farther from the coast
column6: Will be closer to the coast

column2: You are scanning the radar screen for a buoy fitted with racon. How should this signal appear on the PPI display:
column3: As a broken line from center of PPI to the target
column4: Starting with a dash and extending to the right of the target
column5: Starting with a dot and extending radially inward from the target
column6: Starting with a dash and extending radially outward from the target

column2: You are steering a southerly course, and note that the chart predicts an easterly current. Without considering wind, how may you allow for the set?
column3: Head your vessel slightly to the left.
column6: Head your vessel slightly to the right.

column2: You are the person in charge of a lifeboat and have made the decision to beach your craft through a heavy surf. Which of the following is the recommended procedure for a boat under oars?
column3: Keep the head pointed toward the beach, deploy the sea anchor from the stern and row steadily
column4: Keep the head pointed towards the  beach, all oars boated to reduce drag, and control the craft with the tiller
column5: Keep the head into the seas and deploy the sea anchor to control the speed of advancement to the beach
column6: Keep the head into the seas and back smartly to beach the boat in the shortest amount of time

column2: You are towing a vessel and the total length of the tow is more than 200 meters. Which day shape must be exhibited?
column4: One diamond shape, and one black ball

column2: You are trying to rescue survivors from a wrecked vessel on fire. How should you make your approach?
column3: At a speed of at least that of the wrecked vessel
column4: To leeward of the wrecked vessel
column5: At a speed of at most one-half that of the wrecked vessel
column6: To windward of the wrecked vessel

column2: You are underway at 10 knots. At 1800 you note a radar contact dead ahead at a range of 10 miles. At 1812 the contact is dead ahead at a range of 8 miles. The estimated speed of the contact is:

You are underway at 5 knots and see on your radar a contact 10 miles directly astern of you. 12 minutes later, the contact is 8 miles directly astern of you. What is the estimated speed of the contact:
You have anchored in a mud and clay bottom. The anchor appears to be dragging in a storm. What action should you take?
column3: Shorten the scope of the cable.
column6: Drop the second anchor, veer to a good scope, then weigh the first anchor.

column2: You have been observing your radar screen and notice that a contact on the screen has remained in the same position, relative to you, for several minutes. Your vessel is making 10 knots through the water. Which statement is TRUE:
column3: The contact is on a reciprocal course at the same speed as your vessel.
column4: The contact is dead in the water.
column5: The radar is showing false echoes and is probably defective.
column6: The contact is on the same course and speed as your vessel.

column2:
You have completed the magnetic compass adjustments on
magnetic east and magnetic south. The vessel is now
steady on magnetic north but the compass reads 004°.
You should now adjust the compass until it reads:

You have completed the magnetic compass adjustments on
magnetic east and magnetic south. The vessel is now
steady on magnetic west but the compass reads 266°.
What action should be taken?
column3:
Adjust the compass with the athwartships magnets until
the compass reads 268°.
column4:
Adjust the compass with the fore and aft magnets until
the compass reads 270°.
column5:
Adjust the compass with the quadrantal spheres until the
compass reads 274°.
column6:
Adjust the compass with the fore and aft magnets until
the compass reads 268°.

column2: You received a distress call from a vessel sending her position at Lat. 60deg. 00' S; Long. 105deg. 40' W. Your present position is Lat. 60deg. 00' S, Long 100deg. 40' W. What should be the course and distance to the vessel in distress??
You see a yellow light showing above the stern light of the vessel you are overtaking.  The vessel you are overtaking is _________.
You should keep to the __________ of a narrow channel.
You wish to communicate information that the swell in your area is 8-10 feet in height and from the northeast. How would you describe this swell, as defined in the International Code of Signals?
You wish to measure the distance on a Mercator chart between a point in latitude 24°30'S and a point in latitude 28°30'S. To measure 30 miles at a time, you should set the points of the dividers at:
Your vessel is involved in Search and rescue Operations. What is the purpose of the "Situation Report"?
column3: It is used to pass current weather conditions to NOAA for planning purposes
column4: It informs the operating company of the vessel's position
column5: It informs the USCG of any outstanding 835's the vessel may have
column6: It is used to pass information about a particular Search and rescue incident

column2: Your vessel is to unmoor. Two tugs will assist at the unmooring. Which position and how do you want to use the tugs:
column3: Make fast on ship's flat side to keep the vessel in position when unmooring and pull vessel out from the jetty.
column4: Make fast the forward tug, and the aft tug stand by.
column5: Pushing on vessel's flat side to keep the vessel in position when unmooring.
column6: Fast FWD and AFT in center lead to pull the vessel out from the jetty and make it in position for voyage.

column2: Your vessel's heading is 330°pgc and 345°psc with a 2°E gyro error. If there is a variation of 10°W, what is the deviation on this heading?
